question: In patients undergoing lumbar puncture or epidural catheterization, does ultrasound guidance reduce the incidence of traumatic procedures compared with landmark-based techniques? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Ultrasound imaging also significantly reduced the risk of traumatic procedures (risk ratio 0.27 (0.11 to 0.67), P=0.005), the number of insertion attempts (mean difference -0.44 (-0.64 to -0.24), P<0.001), and the number of needle redirections (mean difference -1.00 (-1.24 to -0.75), P<0.001).
content.source_2: Although ultrasound guidance lowers failure rates (risk ratio 0.21, 95% CI 0.10 to 0.43; P<0.001), it did not reduce, and may even increase, the incidence of traumatic procedures (risk ratio 1.12, 95% CI 0.88 to 1.42; P=0.35).
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Ultrasound imaging can reduce the risk of failed or traumatic lumbar punctures and epidural catheterisations, as well as the number of needle insertions and redirections.
content.source_4: In analyses stratified by procedure type, no meaningful differences were detected in traumatic outcomes between ultrasound-guided and landmark techniques (lumbar puncture: risk ratio 0.98, 95% CI 0.71 to 1.35; epidural catheterisation: risk ratio 1.05, 95% CI 0.77 to 1.43; both P>0.20), indicating no reduction in traumatic events with ultrasound.
